results.title: Expanding math skills with the mini-calculator: introduction
results.creator_credit: James M. Smith, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Aesop Films, Susan Norton and Louis Hough
results.brief_description: Many examples demonstrate how teachers can use mini-calculators to motivate and augment learning, check student work, explore number patterns and sequences, examine decimals, estimate solutions and stimulate mathematical curiosity and creativity. Students are shown in class and on field trips as they solve a variety of problems with the calculator. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Expanding math skills with the mini-calculator: classroom management
results.creator_credit: James M. Smith, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Aesop Films and Susan Norton
results.brief_description: Offers practical suggestions for integrating calculators into elementary, advanced and remedial mathematics programs and recommends methods of evaluating students’ progress. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Expanding classroom: Elizabethan village
results.creator_credit: Eileen Molony, British Broadcasting Corporation, Worcestershire Education Authority and G Inger
results.brief_description: The pupils of the senior class at Ashton-under-Hill Primary School reconstruct life in Elizabethan times - constructing wattle-and-daub walls, weaving rush mats, cooking Elizabethan dishes, playing Tudor music, writing with quill pens, writing and giving their own interpretation of witches’ spells, and collecting herbs.

results.title: Expand my boundaries
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Denise VanWyk and ACMI
results.brief_description: When she was given the opportunity to study in Melbourne, Denise VanWyk and her family seized it with both hands. She marvels at her new home, its diversity, acceptance and relaxed atmosphere.

results.title: Exotica
results.creator_credit: Ego Film Arts, Atom Egoyan and Camelia Frieberg
results.brief_description: Considered one of Canadian director Atom Egoyan’s best moments, this film focuses on the lives of individuals as they revolve, in mysterious guises, around The Exotica, an erotic dance club. Taking the idea of the strip tease, and the voyeurism it plays to, Egoyan slowly reveals, in layers, how the lives we are watching on screen are all connected by a singular tragedy from the past. The ultimate truth of this event being saved right up to the very last scene. Cast includes Mia Kirshner and Egoyan regulars Elias Koteas, Arsinee Khanjian, Bruce Greenwood, Don McKellar and Sarah Polley. (Awards: Winner of the International Critics’ Prize Cannes Film Festival 1994)

results.title: Exotic Bali
results.brief_description: An introductory travelogue focusing on the potential tourist attractions that Bali has to offer. Areas included are: Farmlife and market life, cultural ceremonies and way of life, cock fighting, a Balanese funeral procession, cultural ceremonies.

results.title: Exodus
results.brief_description: As the famous theme plays under the opening credits, the tone is set for this powerful, historical drama. Based upon Leon Uris’ international bestseller, “Exodus” chronicles the plight of post-war Jews in their fight to establish a homeland in Israel. Paul Newman gives a compelling performance as a resistance fighter who challenges British authority and brings Jewish refugees into Palestine. Eva Marie Saint is the compassionate American nurse who joins the cause. Their relationship grows as the events of the independence movement swirl around them, and when Sal Mineo, a young Auschwitz survivor, joins in terrorist acts against the British, the screen explodes with tension-filled excitement. Filmed on location in Cyprus and Palestine, this epic drama received several Academy Award nominations and won for Best Score. Also stars Ralph Richardson, John Derek, Peter Lawford and Lee J. Cobb.

results.title: Exits
results.creator_credit: Carolyn Howard, Pat Laughren and Paul Davies
results.brief_description: A personal reaction to the ironies implicit in Remembrance Day, 11 November, 1975. “Exits” is an experimental feature film, one of the first Australian features to merge documentary and enacted elements. The film looks at the effects of the Whitlam sacking on a handful of people wandering the streets, dumps, pubs and public transport of Melbourne. It uses a mixture of radio voice-overs, poems, telexes, headlines and press conferences to set a documentary background against which the growing anger and frustration (or indifference) of the characters can be measured. Rated: G

results.title: Exit No Exit
results.creator_credit: Deanne Edwards and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: This is a love story - both real and imaginary - told in dance and music, and filmed on location in the London Underground. The real world of commuters, buskers and tube trains is the setting for a journey of the imagination. In the underworld beneath the underground a story without words unfolds. Boy meets the girl of his dreams but their love is shattered.
